entry.title: Re: Stock Transfer With Delivery
entry.content:
Hello @Charisma_fitra 

Two-step transfers require PGI to post in ERP first; until IM status flips, GR in inbound delivery can not proceed. Refer to SAP Learning for a quick refresher on the differences between one-step and two-step behaviour. SAP Learning-Performing Stock Transfers Between Storage Locations

Useful SAP documentations 

  • KBA 3364977 — Stuck queues/period change errors; GI status “A”. SAP Support Portal-3364977 - Error message about posting period shows up in Warehouse Monitor app
  • KBA 3578363 — GI/GR posted in EWM but no update/no queue in ERP. SAP Support Portal-3578363 - ERP-relevant messages not sent from EWM
  • KBA 3520582 — GI status inconsistency with no stuck queue. SAP Support Portal-3520582 - GI status inconsistency between EWM and S/4 ERP

Let me know if you need more information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Goods Receipt Slip when posting GR in Inbound delivery
entry.content:
Hello @Lucas2203 

Thank you for your question

Yes, you are right, PPF is not available in public cloud. The Output Management framework is used to print the Good Receipts Slip, which is done through GRPO Output Type.

You can enable it by using the Manage Output Parameter Determination app, then select Inbound Delivery and configure output type GRPO with: Channel = Print, Form Template = GOODS_RECEIPT_PO_SLIP.

Once you are done with that configuration, the slip is then generated automatically when you post Goods Receipts from the Change Inbound Deliveries.

Have a look at  Goods Receipt for Order, Output Parameter Determination  & Maintain Form Templates  for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Joule for Consultants: Listening, Learning, and Delivering
entry.content:
What if it was possible to cut down the time and effort required to implement a large scale digital transformation project without sacrificing quality? In theory, this would mean customers would see the value of their cloud investments materialize much faster than they are today.

That was the bet SAP made when it launched one of its premier Business AI innovations back in December 2024, SAP Joule for Consultants (J4C).  It is a generative AI copilot designed to transform how SAP consultants and partners implement SAP solutions and accelerate cloud transformations. It was born out of a vision where if we could harness the power of generative AI and combine it with SAP's comprehensive knowledge base and business data, we could create a ground-breaking tool that helps millions of SAP consultants augment their productivity, avoid time-consuming searches, and make better-informed decisions at every step of the transformation.

SAP Joule for Consultants is purpose-built as an AI copilot that can deliver concise answers, explain custom code, and provide expert-level best practice guidance. Grounded in SAP's proprietary knowledge base, consultants can rely on the information to be reliable, responsible, and relevant.

Since its General Availability (GA) launch in Q2 2025, product adoption has grown substantially and customers worldwide are beginning to utilize J4C across the various different phases of complex SAP implementation projects.

But GA was only the beginning. The product team has been listening carefully to the feedback from our early adopters, consultants in the field, and our broader SAP Community. The input so far has been incredibly valuable and is helping shape our future roadmap. A consistent theme we have heard is the need to keep enhancing both the Content available in J4C and the overall User Experience. These insights led us narrow our focus on tangible product improvements and has fundamentally guided the August and September product releases.

🚀August Release

User Experience Capabilities:

🔍Prompt Guide with Examples

The new Prompt Guide with Examples helps consultants ask better questions. By clicking Show Prompt Guide above the conversation window, users can see best practices and sample prompts making it easier to frame queries and get better results.

📚Prompt Library

Easily browse a collection of pre-formulated prompts tailored to common roles and areas within SAP. Use filters to find prompts by Role (e.g., Technology Consultant, Project Manager) or Area (e.g., Security Best Practices, ABAP Development).

Each prompt includes:

  • The actual prompt
  • A less effective alternative prompt
  • Prompt objective
  • Prompt description

To use a prompt, simply copy it from the library and paste it into the Joule Conversation box. This feature is accessible via a link in the Quick Prompt Guide.

📋Copy Answer to Clipboard

In addition to the Code Copy you can now quickly copy the entire contents of the Joule answer box by clicking the Copy button. This makes it easy to share Joule’s responses for use in other applications or purposes.

Content Enhancements:

📄Knowledge Base Articles (Public)

 

Public Information from Knowledge-Based Articles is now integrated into SAP Joule for Consultants.

💻Joule for Developers API Assistant

Cloud Content Migration (CCM)

SAP ABAP RESTful

🌐Refreshed Learning and Community Content

 

SAP Learning Journeys & Courses

SAP Community blogs, forums, and Q&A

SAP Roadmap content

🚀September Release

User Experience Capabilities:

⚡Quick Links: A central hub for frequently used features

When you are in the middle of a project, every click matters. Consultants told us that while the Prompt Guide was useful, it was too narrow in scope. They wanted a single-entry point where they could jump to whatever they needed most. That’s why we transformed the old “Show Prompt Guide” button into Quick Links, a central hub designed for speed. With one click, consultants can:

  • Access the Prompt Guide for quick how-to examples.
  • Open the Prompt Library for curated best practices.
  • Check What’s New to stay current with the latest updates.
  • Launch the Console to configure and monitor usage.

🖥️ Control and Clarity with the J4C Console

J4C Console Overview: The new J4C Console brings visibility and control into one place with tailored capabilities for each role (User and Admin).

For All Users: An effortless way to stay on top of what’s new with each release and the Prompt Library to browse and access curated prompts directly from the console.

For Administrators: Admins can use the Console to gain tenant-level insights with Usage Metrics, for tracking adoption and engagement across users, and adjust organizational preferences through Settings, such as starter messages to customize how teams experience J4C.

 

Content Enhancements:

📚KBA and SAP Notes

Access made simple: Entitlement-based access for end-users.

Flexible control: Admins decide who gets access by assigning s-users.

No extra steps: End-users don’t need to act.

🔒Private Content

The SAP Simplification List is a release-specific guide that outlines changes in SAP S/4HANA, detailing which legacy features are removed or replaced and what new solutions take their place. It helps customers and partners understand system impacts, plan conversions, and adopt S/4HANA innovations smoothly.

IMG is a structured guide that provides documentation and activities for adapting standard SAP functions. Users navigate through a hierarchical structure to select and implement desired configurations, ensuring the system functions correctly for their organization.

🌐Content Refresh

Richer insights from SAP Learning & SAP Help.

Access to SAP News & AI Feature Catalogue.

More detailed and comprehensive guidance.

🚀Looking Ahead: We have an ambitious roadmap for the remainder of 2025 and you can expect regular fixes, new capabilities, and innovations. Thank you to SAP colleagues, consultants, and the community for your input and support. Together, we’re shaping the future of AI-powered consulting, guided by your feedback and continuously improving with every release.

entry.title: Re: Data Quality with Artificial Intelligence (AI)
entry.content:
Hi Community,

"Data Cleansing: AI algorithms can identify consistent data patterns, thereby identify data anomalies, correct data errors, missing values. Machine learning models can learn from historical data patterns to predict and fill any missing information.

Data Matching and Deduplication: AI techniques, such as fuzzy matching and clustering algorithms, can identify and merge duplicate records, even when they are not exact matches. This helps in maintaining a single, accurate version of each data entity.

Data Enrichment: AI can enhance data by integrating additional information from external sources. For example, machine learning models can analyse customer data to predict demographic attributes or purchasing behaviour, enriching the existing dataset with valuable insights."

 

Thanks for your selfless sharing, it really help us a lot.

 

🙂

Regards,

ZFiori.

entry.title: Re: Inspection results and specifications from the Semi-F...
entry.content:
Hi @Sindhu_Ravi 

Thank you for your question

In S4HPC, COA retrieves inspection results and specifications from the inspections lot that is associated with the delivered material. Based on your description, the finished goods are referenced. The standard functionality does not allow sourcing results directly from another material’s inspection lot.

If most of your testing is done at the SFG level, you can handle it in two ways:

  1. You can use QM in production copy control to copy relevant result from the SFG inspection lot into the FG inspection lot. Doing that will ensure FG’s lot contains the SFG’S results.
  2. You can use Custom Logic to extend the CoA form to pull inspection results from the SFG lot which is linked through the production order relationship.

Have a look at Quality Certificates, Form Templates & Inspection Lots and Results Recording for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Joule Studio Hands-on October 16th 2025 @ ASUG-WI in Madison Wisconsin
entry.content:
Join us on October 16th in beautiful Madison, Wisconsin for the next ASUG-Wisconsin chapter meeting. 

The meeting will be held on the University of Wisconsin - Madison campus at the Pyle Center right in the heart of campus with a fantastic view of Lake Mendota. 

We have a great agenda planned and for those of you looking to get your hands-on Joule Studio in SAP Build then this is the event for you.  We will have a 3-hr hands-on session as part of this event along with a great session about Madison-based company Accuray and their journey from Microsoft Dynamics ERP to SAP S/4HANA including their use of SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Integration Suite.

Be sure to Register NOW as there will be limited seating for the hands-on session.  

The 3-hour hands-on session will explore how Joule Studio enables developers and technical professionals to design, build, and deploy intelligent AI skills and agents within SAP’s ecosystem.

Why Joule Studio?
Learn the purpose and value of Joule Studio as part of SAP’s broader AI framework. Understand how it connects data, applications, and processes to deliver intelligent, context-aware solutions.

What You Can Build
Discover the wide range of possibilities with Joule Studio—from automating workflows and enhancing business operations to building conversational assistants that support real-time decision-making.

Let’s Build a Joule Skill (Hands-On)
Follow a guided, step-by-step exercise to create your first Joule skill. Learn how to define inputs, design logic, and test your skill in the Joule Studio environment.

Art of Creating Your Own Agents
Dive deeper into the process of designing, configuring, and orchestrating agents. Understand best practices for managing agent behaviors, optimizing performance, and ensuring seamless collaboration between skills.

Illustrative Use Cases
See how organizations are applying Joule Studio in real scenarios—from HR virtual assistants and procurement insights to IT automation and operational analytics.

Resources and Next Steps
Wrap up with guidance on additional enablement materials, documentation, and community resources to help you continue developing with Joule Studio.

Join Global VP Lester Lobo and Rugved Chavan, Data Engineering and AI Specialist, as they lead us through this hands-on session.  

Register Now to join us in Madison on October 16th!

entry.title: Learn more about Fiscalization 2.0 in Croatia: e-invoicing (B2B) , fiscalization and e-reporting
entry.content:
Regulatory Changes  As part of the "Fiscalization 2.0" project and starting January 2026, the Croatian government is introducing B2B e-invoicing, e-reporting and fiscalization requirements. 

  • B2B/B2G e-invoicing: all businesses with VAT registration in Croatia need to send electronic invoices in the required format through an approved service provider.
  • Fiscalization: 
    • B2B/B2G invoices: issuer and receiver of e-invoices need to send the fiscal data of the invoice to authorities (digitally signed XML). 
    • B2C invoices: issuer of the e-invoice needs to send fiscal to authorities irrespective of payment method (currently required only for cash payments). 
  • E-reporting: in addition to invoicing data (fiscalization), the following reporting requirements need to be fulfilled: 
    • List of collected invoices (payment received), during reporting period (month) for invoice issuer. 
    • List of outbound deliveries for which e-invoice could not be delivered, during reporting period (month) for invoice issuer. 
    • List of rejected invoices, during reporting period (month) for invoice recipient. 

The first e-reporting submission deadline is Feb 20, 2026, for the month of January 2026. This is the date by when all invoice statuses (rejected / not delivered as recipient is not in the ‘address book’) and payments received need to be sent, but they can be sent continuously during the period invoice by invoice. 

Planned SAP Solution SAP plans to support businesses in meeting these new requirements leveraging SAP Document and Reporting Compliance. This cloud-based solution offers end-to-end compliance for more than 55 countries, natively embedded into the ERP, without the need for data replication and reconciliation. 
To find our more and see in action how regulatory requirements in Croatia will be supported, mark your calendar on October 16, 2025, at 3:30pm CET and join our webinar covering the new Fiscalization, B2B e-Invoicing, and e-Reporting requirements in Croatia.  Register today and you'll:  

  • Gain insight on upcoming regulatory mandates 
  • Understand how SAP Document and Reporting Compliance supports these changes 
  • Learn how to prepare your system with necessary implementation and configuration  

Share with your peers, the webinar is free and can also be watched on demand afterwards.  

Delivery Status  Please monitor Regulatory Change Manager application to stay updated about the planned scope, delivery timeline and solution details: 

  •  B2B e-invoicing for domestic customer invoice and supplier invoice, last mile provider required: link  
  •  Send Fiscalization data to tax authorities: link 
  •  e-reporting presenting list of collected invoices during reporting period (month) for invoice issuer: link 

More information 

  • Official publication of the Fiscalization Act in the official Gazette (in Croatian) 
  • Legal changes published by Tax Authority (in Croatian):
    • https://planoporavka.gov.hr/UserDocsImages/dokumenti/Plan%20oporavka%20i%20otpornosti,%20srpanj%202021..pdf?vel=13435491 
    • https://porezna.gov.hr/fiskalizacija/bezgotovinski-racuni/fiskalizacija-bezgotovinskih-racuna
  • Customer & Partner Facing Workzones for Croatia link I Q&A  
  • Regulatory Change Manager for all countries and topics    
  • SAP Roadmap for Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)  
  • Other Regional Collaboration Workzones - Request access by clicking on the topic/region of interest 
  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Community  
  • SAP Help for DRC link 
  • You Tube Video Channel on SAP DRC

entry.title: Client-Side Column Encryption fails in Cloud Foundry (JDBC) with -11503
entry.content:
Summary
A Java app running on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry connects to SAP HANA over TLS without issues, but any query that touches client-side encrypted columns fails with:
 
SAP DBTech JDBC: [11503]: Column encryption key with ID <cek-uuid-redacted> could not be retrieved from the server.
No local client key pairs have access to this key.
 
Unencrypted queries work. The exact same PKCS#12 + PIN decrypts the same column via hdbsql on the origin machine and returns valid plaintext, so the key material in the CF app is correct and matches the CEK used by that column. In CF via JDBC it consistently ends in -11503, which looks like a generic “CSE not OK” gate rather than literally “no local key pairs.”
 
Impact
• All reads/writes that touch encrypted columns fail.
• Features depending on those columns are effectively down.
• Connectivity, TLS validation, and non-encrypted operations remain OK.
 
Environment
• Platform: SAP BTP / Cloud Foundry (Java, SAP Java Buildpack, Tomcat)
• Database: SAP HANA Cloud (single DB)
• ORM: JPA / EclipseLink
• JDBC driver: SAP HANA JDBC 2.25 (from runtime logs)
• Service bindings (VCAP):
– HANA: <pp-schema-redacted>
– Credential Store: <pp-credstore-redacted>
• Keystore: fetched at runtime from SAP Credential Store (mTLS + JWE), written to a temp file in CF; PIN retrieved separately from CredStore
• CEK observed in error: <cek-uuid-redacted>
 
Current JDBC configuration (sanitized)
 
jdbc:sap://<db-id-redacted>.hana.prod-<region-redacted>.hanacloud.ondemand.com:443
  ?encrypt=true
  &validateCertificate=true
  &currentschema=<schema-redacted>
  &cseKeyStore=<temp-path-redacted>
  &cseKeyStorePassword=****    <-- PIN
  &cseKeyStoreType=PKCS12
  &cseKeyStoreAlias=init
  &traceFile=<trace-path-redacted>
  &traceLevel=3
  &traceOptions=CSE
 
Timeline / Evidence (sanitized)
1. Connectivity, TLS, driver init OK
Startup logs show:
• HANA binding resolved: service <pp-schema-redacted>, database_id <db-id-redacted>
• JDBC driver version 2.25
• TLS on (encrypt=true, validateCertificate=true), server cert validation passed
2. Keystore from Credential Store loads and unlocks
• “Initializing CSCE from CredStore: binding <pp-credstore-redacted>, namespace <ns-redacted>”
• “Keystore fetched: path cse-keystore-<random>.p12, size , pinPresent=true”
• “Loaded entry: alias init, entryType=PrivateKeyEntry, unlockable=true”
• Cert subject and SHA-256 fingerprint logged (masked)
3. Failure occurs when the driver retrieves CEK metadata
First query touching an encrypted column throws:
 
SQLNonTransientConnectionExceptionSapDB:
  Column encryption key with ID <cek-uuid-redacted> could not be retrieved from the server.
  No local client key pairs have access to this key. (Error -11503)
  at com.sap.db.jdbc.ConnectionSapDB.retrieveColumnEncryptionKey(...)
  at com.sap.db.jdbc.packet.HReplyPacket.getResultSetMetaData(...)
  at com.sap.db.jdbc.PreparedStatementSapDB._handlePrepareReply(...)
 
4. Minimal “PIN-only” configuration behaves the same
Tried the lean setup suggested in docs: only cseKeyStorePassword (PIN), omitting explicit keystore path/type/alias. Result is still -11503. This points away from path/alias/type resolution problems.
5. Ground truth: the very same key pair works with hdbsql
• Using the same PKCS#12 + PIN on the origin Windows machine, hdbsql decrypts the target encrypted column and returns valid plaintext.
• The same key pair imported into a fresh PKCS#12 on Linux and used in CF still results in -11503.
• keytool -list -v confirms alias=init, private key present and unlockable, fingerprint consistent.
→ The private keys in the app’s keystore on the server are exactly the same keys that successfully decrypt the column via hdbsql. They match the CEK for that column.
 
Notes
• Earlier tests showed hdbkeystore Export produces a container not readable by keytool/openssl (meant for hdbkeystore re-import). That path is not used in CF.
 
What we’ve tried (summary)
• Verified TLS and connectivity.
• Enabled CSE tracing (traceLevel=3, traceOptions=CSE).
• Sourced keystore + PIN from Credential Store; also tested fresh PKCS#12 built on Linux.
• Tested minimal “PIN-only” JDBC config.
• Confirmed with hdbsql that the same key pair decrypts the same column successfully.
 
Findings
• The keystore in CF loads; alias=init is a PrivateKeyEntry and unlocks with the PIN.
• The failure appears exactly at the CEK retrieval/mapping step.
• Error -11503 here likely serves as a generic “CSE chain not acceptable” signal.
• Since hdbsql with the same key pair decrypts the same column, the key is valid and matches the CEK; the discrepancy is environmental/behavioral between CF+JDBC and the working hdbsql setup.
 
Open questions
1. Why does the exact same PKCS#12 + PIN combination decrypt the column with hdbsql but fail with JDBC in CF?
2. In this path, what does -11503 precisely represent—strictly “no matching recipient,” or any broader CSE precondition failure?
3. Which diagnostics would show the CEK metadata resolved by JDBC in CF and how it’s being matched to the client certificate?
4. Could schema/tenant/database context differ between CF and the origin machine, causing a different CEK or metadata to be used?
5. Are there driver/runtime specifics in CF (buildpack, JCE, deferredPrepare, etc.) that could change how the CEK/recipient mapping is evaluated?

• “Loaded entry: alias init, entryType=PrivateKeyEntry, unlockable=true”
• Cert subject and SHA-256 fingerprint logged (masked)
3. Failure occurs when the driver retrieves CEK metadata
First query touching an encrypted column throws:
 
SQLNonTransientConnectionExceptionSapDB:
  Column encryption key with ID <cek-uuid-redacted> could not be retrieved from the server.
  No local client key pairs have access to this key. (Error -11503)
  at com.sap.db.jdbc.ConnectionSapDB.retrieveColumnEncryptionKey(...)
  at com.sap.db.jdbc.packet.HReplyPacket.getResultSetMetaData(...)
  at com.sap.db.jdbc.PreparedStatementSapDB._handlePrepareReply(...)
 
4. Minimal “PIN-only” configuration behaves the same
Tried the lean setup suggested in docs: only cseKeyStorePassword (PIN), omitting explicit keystore path/type/alias. Result is still -11503. This points away from path/alias/type resolution problems.
5. Ground truth: the very same key pair works with hdbsql
• Using the same PKCS#12 + PIN on the origin Windows machine, hdbsql decrypts the target encrypted column and returns valid plaintext.
• The same key pair imported into a fresh PKCS#12 on Linux and used in CF still results in -11503.
• keytool -list -v confirms alias=init, private key present and unlockable, fingerprint consistent.
→ The private keys in the app’s keystore on the server are exactly the same keys that successfully decrypt the column via hdbsql. They match the CEK for that column.
 
Notes
• Earlier tests showed hdbkeystore Export produces a container not readable by keytool/openssl (meant for hdbkeystore re-import). That path is not used in CF.
 
What we’ve tried (summary)
• Verified TLS and connectivity.
• Enabled CSE tracing (traceLevel=3, traceOptions=CSE).
• Sourced keystore + PIN from Credential Store; also tested fresh PKCS#12 built on Linux.
• Tested minimal “PIN-only” JDBC config.
• Confirmed with hdbsql that the same key pair decrypts the same column successfully.
 
Findings
• The keystore in CF loads; alias=init is a PrivateKeyEntry and unlocks with the PIN.
• The failure appears exactly at the CEK retrieval/mapping step.
• Error -11503 here likely serves as a generic “CSE chain not acceptable” signal.
• Since hdbsql with the same key pair decrypts the same column, the key is valid and matches the CEK; the discrepancy is environmental/behavioral between CF+JDBC and the working hdbsql setup.
 
Open questions
1. Why does the exact same PKCS#12 + PIN combination decrypt the column with hdbsql but fail with JDBC in CF?
2. In this path, what does -11503 precisely represent—strictly “no matching recipient,” or any broader CSE precondition failure?
3. Which diagnostics would show the CEK metadata resolved by JDBC in CF and how it’s being matched to the client certificate?
4. Could schema/tenant/database context differ between CF and the origin machine, causing a different CEK or metadata to be used?
5. Are there driver/runtime specifics in CF (buildpack, JCE, deferredPrepare, etc.) that could change how the CEK/recipient mapping is evaluated?

entry.title: Re: FM DATE_CHECK_PLAUSIBILITY checks User default date f...
entry.content:
My Sample program to explain about this FM

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report Z_DATE_PLAUSIBILITY_CHECK
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Simple program to demonstrate FM DATE_CHECK_PLAUSIBILITY
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT z_date_plausibility_check.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Data Declarations
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
DATA: lv_date TYPE sy-datum,
lv_check_rule TYPE t009b-xperi,
lv_interval_years TYPE t009b-xperi VALUE 5,
lv_interval_months TYPE t009b-permo VALUE 12,
lv_return_code TYPE sy-subrc,
lv_message TYPE string.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Selection Screen
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b1 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-001.
PARAMETERS: p_date TYPE sy-datum DEFAULT sy-datum OBLIGATORY.
PARAMETERS: p_years TYPE numc2 DEFAULT 5,
p_months TYPE numc2 DEFAULT 12.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b1.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Initialization
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
INITIALIZATION.
TEXT-001 = 'Date Plausibility Check Parameters'.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Main Program
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
START-OF-SELECTION.

WRITE: / 'Date Plausibility Check Program',
/ sy-uline(70).
SKIP 1.

" Display input parameters
WRITE: / 'Date to Check:', p_date DD/MM/YYYY.
WRITE: / 'Today''s Date:', sy-datum DD/MM/YYYY.
WRITE: / 'Year Tolerance:', p_years, 'years'.
WRITE: / 'Month Tolerance:', p_months, 'months'.
SKIP 1.
WRITE: / sy-uline(70).

" Call the function module
CALL FUNCTION 'DATE_CHECK_PLAUSIBILITY'
EXPORTING
date = p_date
date_for_check = sy-datum
* DISPLAY = ' '
* FACTORY_CALENDAR = ' '
IMPORTING
plausibility_check_failed = lv_return_code
EXCEPTIONS
plausibility_check_failed = 1
OTHERS = 2.

SKIP 1.

" Check the result
CASE sy-subrc.
WHEN 0.
" Date is plausible
WRITE: / '✓ Result: Date is PLAUSIBLE',
/ 'The date passed the plausibility check.',
/ 'This date can be used in business transactions.'.
FORMAT COLOR COL_POSITIVE.
WRITE: / 'STATUS: OK'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.

WHEN 1.
" Date is not plausible
WRITE: / '✗ Result: Date is NOT PLAUSIBLE',
/ 'The date failed the plausibility check.',
/ 'This date is outside acceptable range.'.
FORMAT COLOR COL_NEGATIVE.
WRITE: / 'STATUS: ERROR'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.

" Show reason
SKIP 1.
WRITE: / 'Possible reasons:'.
IF p_date < sy-datum.
WRITE: / '- Date is too far in the PAST'.
ELSE.
WRITE: / '- Date is too far in the FUTURE'.
ENDIF.

WHEN OTHERS.
WRITE: / '? Result: UNEXPECTED ERROR',
/ 'An unexpected error occurred during check.'.
FORMAT COLOR COL_TOTAL.
WRITE: / 'STATUS: UNKNOWN'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.
ENDCASE.

" Additional date analysis
SKIP 1.
WRITE: / sy-uline(70).
WRITE: / 'Additional Analysis:'.

DATA: lv_diff_days TYPE i.
lv_diff_days = p_date - sy-datum.

IF lv_diff_days = 0.
WRITE: / '- Date is TODAY'.
ELSEIF lv_diff_days > 0.
WRITE: / '- Date is', lv_diff_days, 'days in the FUTURE'.
ELSE.
lv_diff_days = lv_diff_days * -1.
WRITE: / '- Date is', lv_diff_days, 'days in the PAST'.
ENDIF.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Example with Multiple Test Cases
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
TOP-OF-PAGE.
WRITE: / 'SAP Date Plausibility Check - Demo Program',
/ 'Report: Z_DATE_PLAUSIBILITY_CHECK',
/ sy-uline(70).
SKIP 1.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Test Different Scenarios (Optional - Comment out if not needed)
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
END-OF-SELECTION.
SKIP 2.
WRITE: / sy-uline(70).
WRITE: / 'TEST SCENARIOS:'.
WRITE: / sy-uline(70).
SKIP 1.

" Test Case 1: Current date
PERFORM check_date USING sy-datum 'Current Date (Today)'.

" Test Case 2: Very old date
PERFORM check_date USING '19900101' 'Very Old Date (1990)'.

" Test Case 3: Future date
DATA: lv_future TYPE sy-datum.
lv_future = sy-datum + 365.
PERFORM check_date USING lv_future 'One Year in Future'.

" Test Case 4: Far future date
PERFORM check_date USING '20500101' 'Far Future (2050)'.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Subroutine to check date
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM check_date USING p_test_date TYPE sy-datum
p_desc TYPE string.

DATA: lv_rc TYPE sy-subrc.

WRITE: / 'Testing:', p_desc.
WRITE: / 'Date:', p_test_date DD/MM/YYYY.

CALL FUNCTION 'DATE_CHECK_PLAUSIBILITY'
EXPORTING
date = p_test_date
date_for_check = sy-datum
IMPORTING
plausibility_check_failed = lv_rc
EXCEPTIONS
plausibility_check_failed = 1
OTHERS = 2.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
FORMAT COLOR COL_POSITIVE.
WRITE: / '→ Result: PASSED ✓'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.
ELSE.
FORMAT COLOR COL_NEGATIVE.
WRITE: / '→ Result: FAILED ✗'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.
ENDIF.

SKIP 1.

ENDFORM.

entry.title: Welcome to the Future: The 2H 2025 Home Page Redesign in SuccessFactors
entry.content:
SAP is gearing up to unveil a refreshed and enhanced Home Page experience as part of the 2H 2025 SuccessFactors release. This update aims to make the Home Page more intuitive, dynamic, and tailored to each user’s context — helping reduce friction, speed up access to core tasks, and deliver a modern “landing pad” for day-to-day HR workflows.

 

Key Highlights & Enhancements

  1. Quick Actions — smarter and more flexible

The Quick Actions section will be more context‑aware, surfacing actions that are most relevant to each user (based on their permissions, modules, and usage patterns). You’ll notice faster access to high-value tasks without navigating multiple screens.

SAP is also introducing integration of Quick Actions into SuccessFactors Work Zone — bringing HR actions into the broader workplace context.

  1. Opt‑In / Disable Controls

Some of the Home Page changes are opt-in or configurable, giving you control over timing and adoption. For organizations that prefer gradual rollout or selective adoption, this offers valuable flexibility.

  1. Visual & Layout Refinements

Expect cleaner layouts, more consistent card design, and an improved information hierarchy so that important items stand out.

  1. Better Support for Dynamic Content & Cards

Custom cards will get improved support for embedding iFrames, videos, and rich content — providing greater flexibility. As with earlier redesigns, content will be dynamically driven — only what is relevant to the user will appear.

Why This Matters — Benefits to Your Organization

Benefit

Description

Enhance User Productivity

By surfacing relevant actions and reducing navigation steps, users get to their tasks faster.

Contextual Experience

The Home Page adapts to each user’s role, reducing noise and cognitive overload.

Modern Look & Feel

A refreshed interface aligns with contemporary standards and user expectations.

Scalable Customization

Embedded rich content and advanced card capabilities allow tailoring without heavy customization.

Controlled Adoption

Opt-in and configurable options let you manage change at your own pace.

Rollout Strategy: How to Plan Your Adoption

  1. Early Preview & Sandbox Testing — Enable the new Home Page in test environments and gather feedback.
  2. Feature Mapping & Gap Analysis — Map existing content to new cards and identify unsupported elements.
  3. Define Card Visibility & Prioritization — Decide which cards show for each role and configure rules accordingly.
  4. Performance & UX Testing — Test responsiveness across devices and monitor page loading times.
  5. User Communication & Training — Provide clear communication, training, and guided tours.
  6. Staged Rollout / Opt-In Phases — Start with pilot users before full rollout.
  7. Monitor, Iterate & Optimize — Track feedback and analytics to fine-tune the experience.

Sample Narrative to Use Internally / Communicate to Users

We’re excited to bring you a refreshed Home Page in the 2H 2025 SuccessFactors update. This new version is smarter, cleaner, and more personalized — putting the actions you use most front and center. Over the coming weeks, we’ll roll this out to a pilot group, gather feedback, and gradually expand to all users.

Final Thoughts

The redesigned Home Page in the 2H 2025 release represents a meaningful evolution in how users interact with SuccessFactors. With careful planning, testing, and change management, organizations can make this transition seamless and impactful.

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: AI-Assisted Generation of Trade Classification Proposals
entry.content:
Trade product classification is the key processes of assigning specific legal codes to products (tangible or not) being exported or imported. the organization of these goods into a nomenclature according to customs and foreign trade law.

This code, the product classification, determines which tariffs, taxes, additional duties, trade defense measures, and import & export formalities to apply to the products in a specific country. So, something quite important to get right!

The most widely used global system for this purpose is the Harmonized System (HS), developed by the World Customs Organization (WCO).

On paper, this is a very straight forward process as it is supported by rules of interpretation and explanatory notes broken down into 21 sections consisting of:

  • 97 chapters determining the broad category of products (first 2 digits of the code)
  • Approximately 1,200 headings defining the type of product within the given chapter (next 2 digits)
  • Over 5,000 sub-headings for the detailed description of the product itself (last 2 digits)

Together, this “decision tree” approach provides a 6-digit categorization that is the basis for authorities in more than 200 countries and territories to check whether legal requirements are met, define the customs duties, collect international trade statistics, etc. It further represents the link between the product master data and the importing and exporting requirements.

Sounds simple, right? Well, if you are reading this blog then I am pretty sure you are already aware of the inherent intricacies to achieve accurate classification.

Some products with ambiguous or numerous components might not fit neatly into the standard classification categories so will require thorough product analysis and detailed technical specifications to correctly classify the product. And, even when the product itself is not complex, Trade Classification Specialists might be facing another issue: missing or incomplete product details such as composition, dimensions, intended use, or technical specifications.

Furthermore, at the corporate level, since the process is mostly manual and prone to interpretation, similar products classified by 2 specialists may have different classifications based on minor differences and can lead to underpayment or overpayment of duties, fines from customs authorities, shipment holds, or even legal penalties.

This is where software vendors can help Trade Classification Specialists: automate the process, with still a human-in-the-loop to ensure that the final decision relies on human expertise and experience.

In response to this challenge and to assist Trade Classification Specialists with dedicated automation, the SAP Product Management and Engineering teams have worked with customers from various geographies and locations to release 2 functionalities in the SAP S/4HANA for international trade module: by product similarity and using Agentic AI.

 

AI-Assisted Generation of Trade Classification Proposals by Product Similarity

 

In this first approach already available since SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, trade classification proposals for custom tariff numbers and commodity codes are assigned to products through a similarity search of existing product classifications using SAP HANA fuzzy search technology. By looking at historical data and searching for similar products based on the comparison of the product descriptions, the capability can generate a product classification proposal.

In short, for every trade classification number assigned to a similar product, a proposal is generated by the system and the accuracy of the proposal is derived from the number of products.

For instance, there is an unclassified product, and you already have 3 other classified products with the same description. If 2 of them are classified with X and the other one with Y, the accuracy of proposal X is 67% and the accuracy of proposal Y is 33%.

Illustration of “Activate Classification Proposals – Customer Tariff Numbers” Fiori App

Further enhancements are also already planned in the SAP Roadmap Explorer for this feature: Additional functionality for AI-assisted trade classification proposals with fuzzy search

 

International Trade Classification Agent

 

It won’t have escaped you that we are amid a “rise of the machines” era and making more and more use of artificial intelligence – including Generative and Agentic AI.

To further support product classification, and especially for cases where there is a new product that doesn’t have similarities with previous ones or there were significant changes in the product itself or for any other reason, a second approach is being released. It is not yet live but in the final stages of customer validation.

Here, the capability doesn’t rely on historical data and instead leverages Generative AI.

In this case, the agentic AI capability can use the product information details and, using pre-trained classification, analyze the text, profile the product and match its profile with established standards and then propose a relevant . And include of course the context-driven justifications that is kept for auditability purposes.

This second approach using Generative AI is planned to be available soon, but a forward-looking video has already been released based on the scenario in validation. So, let’s see the feature in action:

 

See it live!

 

If you would like to learn more about these capabilities and even see them live, then I would suggest registering for the SAP for Global Trade and Tax Conference on November 12 - 13, 2025 in Rome.

During this event, Steffen Kübler - Product Manager for International Trade in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, will be delivering a dedicated session: “SAP Live Demo - Discover Assisted International Trade Product Classification Capabilities in SAP” that will answer all your remaining questions and more.

What about you, how does your company support the Trade Classification experts? I look forward to reading your thoughts and comments on this blog.

And if you are interested in learning more about SAP solutions for Governance, Risk, and Compliance, feel free to fill-in the demo request form!

entry.title: Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/ BW-IP in SAP BDC
entry.content:
This blog post is a joint work of @IsabelWichmann and @irinasheftelevich 

Financial Planner´s Overview page in SAP Analytics Cloud

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC (THIS BLOG POST)
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self – service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) is a fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data, giving line-of-business leaders context to make even more impactful decisions. As an evolution of our industry-leading data, planning, and analytics solutions, SAP Business Data Cloud brings together SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse with a unified experience that delivers transformational insights across all lines of business. 

To fully leverage benefits of SAP BDC in the Planning and Analytics area, it is worth to consider modernizing the Planning engine.  SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is the component that delivers cutting-edge analytics and planning capabilities while providing real-time insights powered by AI and machine learning. It integrates seamlessly with SAP Datasphere to offer a unified data analysis experience (The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The ... - SAP Community).

But how to get there? For those customers who are searching for a new planning engine the situation is clear. SAC is the clear strategic direction for the planning processes and xP&A. For those customers who are now using an SAP BW based planning engine like SAP BPC or BW-IP the path can be not as straightforward, so we are recommending evaluating the possible ways to start with SAP BDC as the future-state landscape.

SAP BPC PLANNING SCENARIOS WITHIN SAP BDC

There are three scenarios how you can go forward with SAP Business Planning and Consolidation (SAP BPC) as part of SAP BDC.

Based on insights from the original SAP blog on moving from SAP BPC to SAC, we would like to refresh and update scenarios of moving from SAP BPC —into the world of SAP BDC and SAC.

SCENARIO 1: MOVE

Picture 1: Moving to SAC planning at your own pace

Target Landscape: SAC Planning + BDC as the data foundation

This is the option where planning use cases would be completely moved from SAP BPC into SAC. In this case we talk about re-implementation, but you can still reuse some of the things that you have created. For example, you could build a SAC planning model based on the query that is coming from your SAP BPC (embedded model, running on the SAP BW system). That way all relevant dimensions (including its members and hierarchies) could be recreated quite easily. 

What´s new with SAP BDC?

  1. Seamless planning, links SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with SAP Datasphere so that SAC model data (facts & master data) can be stored directly in Datasphere. This reduces data duplication, ensures real-time availability, and allows further processing and extension via Datasphere’s capabilities. ( Seamless planning between SAP Analytics Cloud and ... - SAP Community )
  2. Part of BW modernisation process. SAP Analytics cloud can replace SAP BPC and BW-IP, become the new modern planning engine and reduce dependency on SAP BW. It can help to shrink BW and together with SAP Profitability and Performance management solution and Datasphere can provide a foundation for an End-to-End enterprise performance management process.

SCENARIO 2: COMPLEMENT (=LIVE Planning)

Picture 2: Live Planning

In this scenario we are using SAC as a planning/forecasting data entry UX and as well for data analysis (variance analysis in reports and dashboards for example). In other words, users enter data via the SAC data entry form, and the data is being persisted directly in the SAP BPC embedded planning model. No data is being stored in SAC whatsoever. This scenario allows to:

  • Retain existing BPC / BW-IP models
  • Provide attractive & powerful UX to end users for:
    • Data entry
    • Analysis
    • Mobile iOS / Android apps (analysis only)
  • Use SAC Catalog for unified access to all content

What´s new with SAP BDC?

SAP BPC can be first migrated with BW into SAP BDC, modernizing data architecture. SAC can be introduced gradually, being a front end to existing SAP BPC embedded models and planning logic.

SCENARIO 3: ADD (Extend SAP BPC with SAC for new functional plans)

Picture 3: Extend SAP BPC with SAC for new functional plans

In this scenario, we can build new functional plans on top of SAP BPC with SAC and then we provide integration (data is replicated in both directions between SAP BPC and SAC). A simple example of such integration could be to bring an initial version of sales forecast from SAP BPC model into SAC model (model – dimensions & measures; with data is being replicated from SAP BPC into SAC). In the next step predictive time series forecasting would be applied on top of forecast data stored in SAC model. If needed, users could perform some manual adjustments or allocations and when done the updated forecast would be replicated back to SAP BPC model.

What´s new with SAP BDC?

As with Live scenario, SAP BPC can be first migrated with BW into SAP BDC, modernizing your data architecture. SAC can be introduced gradually, not only as front-end, but also as a planning engine, allowing phased transition into strategic solution.

For scenario 2+3 withing SAP BDC: BPC should be moved into BPC PCE of SAP BDC architecture.  This move is supported for BPC NetWeaver as well as BPC on BW/4HANA. See picture below:

Picture 4: Migration of SAP BPC versions to SAP BDC

 

BUT WHY MAKE THIS MOVE?

There are several strategic and technical benefits of SAP BPC PCE in SAP Business Data Cloud:

Strategic Benefits

  • Fully aligned with SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Follow the clean core principle: reduce custom extensions management costs
  • Application and technical operations from one vendor
  • Mainstream maintenance until 2030 for SAP BPC 10.1 and 2040 for SAP BPC 11  (BPC/4HANA)

Technical Benefits

  • Support for hybrid planning with both SAP BPC and SAC
  • Scalable platform
  • Continue to leverage SAP BW capabilities

FINAL THOUGHT

SAC/SAP BDC emerging as the new standard, now is the time to choose your path forward. Whether you go all-in on SAC, transition gradually via SAP BW PCE on SAP BDC, or start with seamless integration — SAP Business Data Cloud ensures your planning is built on a trusted, unified data foundation.

Would like to know more?

Check out the BPC MOVE blog series and this further information to learn more about the transition from SAP BPC to SAP Analytics Cloud:

  • Enabling BPC Runtime-license: https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/3150518The SAP Note 2969947provides you the latest information of the supported and unsupported planning functionalities when using an SAC Model based on a BPC Live connection.
  • Easily transition from BPC to SAC-P: https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/cloud-analytics/move-planning.html
  • SAP Note 3308697 with SAP BPC Standard Migration guide

Ready to take the next step?

Start your cloud migration journey. Contact us at movebpc@sap.com to learn more about using SAP Analytics Cloud for Planning to migrate your SAP BPC investment to the Cloud and accelerate your business & financial transformation.

Please check out also SAP Note 3308697 with SAP BPC Standard and BPC Embedded Migration guide (two migration guides pdfs).

(Fairly) new to SAP Analytics Cloud?

Find out how to apply the basics of modelling, planning, analysing and administration with SAP’s free learning resources on SAP Analytics Cloud. The learning journey is designed for business users who want to upskill and boost their careers. Check out even more role-based learning resources and opportunities to get certified in one place on SAP Learning site.

entry.title: Re: Unavailability of Released CDS view for Warehouse tas...
entry.content:
Hello @VK2025 

Check these SAP Knowledge Base Articles related to your issue.:

KBA 3504675 – “CDS View is ‘Not Released’ in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition”
It states that CDS Views, which are not released, cannot be used in custom logic or key-user extensibility; if a view is unreleased, you cannot rely on it in your scenario. SAP Support Portal-3504675 - CDS View is "Not Released" in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Also, KBA 3434190 – “Warehouse Task not reflected in CDS View I_EWM_WAREHOUSETASK_2”
It mentions that for certain warehouse documents (handling unit, material document), SAP has not yet released CDS views. SAP Support Portal-3434190 - Warehouse Task not reflected in CDS View I_EWM_WAREHOUSETASK_2

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Using Document Management as a Content Repository with SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Dear @Meghana_2025 / Kapil,

You cannot connect HTTP content server as a storage for BTP DMS. SAP HTTP content server does not follow CMIS protocol and thus you cannot use it as a storage for your BTP DMS. 

Best Regards

SSB

entry.title: Spatial Functions in ABAP SQL
entry.content:
Why is the coffee shop Coffee for You in street X more popular than Coffee Beans in street Y? It could be that the coffee is just better in street X or that they have special offers that bind their customers. But it could also be as simple as the location. If you want to set up a store, it’s helpful to know if customers would come by or if there are competitors that could threaten your business. To find the best location, you can get help using spatial data.

Spatial data gives you information about the location of an object or event on the surface of the Earth. Other attributes, such as timestamps, can also be linked to the object or event. Doing so gives more opportunities to analyze the data and even predict behaviors. Representing spatial data is often done using 2D geometries, but can also take other forms. The typical geometrical forms are points, lines, and polygons.

Working with Spatial Data in ABAP

With ABAP Release 9.15, SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2505 functions were added to ABAP SQL to access, manipulate, and analyze spatial data in ABAP. These implemented functions are mapped to methods, functions, and constructors in SAP HANA. In the following demo, you will learn how to use ABAP SQL spatial functions.

Use Case: EMODnet Maps

The European Marine Observation and Data Network (EMODnet) offers maps like the vessel density map to visualize, for example, movement patterns and maritime traffic distribution. In a press release, EOMDnet explains the map's importance by, for example, “monitoring shipping emissions” and “planning offshore wind farms” (https://emodnet.ec.europa.eu/en/new-insights-european-maritime-traffic-emodnet-vessel-density-maps).

For the demo, we will extract the vessel density map's geometry data in JSON format using an Open Geospatial Consortium web service. In particular, we will examine the port locations in Europe using the following URL:

https://ows.emodnet-humanactivities.eu/wfs?service=WFS&version=2.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeNames=emodnet:portlocations&outputFormat=application/json.

This request returns the geometry data for each port. One entry is, for example:

{
   "type":"Feature",
   "id":"portlocations.16",
   "geometry":
   {
    "type":"Point",
    "coordinates":
    [
     4.40815,
     51.24165
    ]
   },
   "geometry_name":"the_geom",
   "properties":
   {
    "port_id":"BE003",
    "data_src_c":"0",
    "port_coor_":null,
    "country":"BE",
    "portname":null,
    "port":"Antwerp-Bruges",
    "source":"Port of Antwerp-Bruges",
    "pointx":4.40815,
    "pointy":51.24165,
    "traffic":"1"
   }
}

Having retrieved this information, we want to display all the ports in an SVG graphic.

Visualizing Spatial Data as SVG

To visualize all the European ports as SVG, the geodata must be available in a database table. You can do so by uploading the JSON file or calling the web service API in ABAP. The second solution can look like this:

method return_wfs_getfeature.
  DATA(wfs_features_url) = `https://ows.emodnet-humanactivities.eu/wfs?service=WFS&version=2.0.0` &&
                           `&request=GetFeature&typeNames=emodnet:portlocations&outputFormat=application/json`.

  cl_http_client=>create_by_url( exporting url  = wfs_features_url
                                 importing client = DATA(client) ).

  client->request->set_method( if_rest_message=>gc_method_get ).
  client->send( ).
  client->receive( exceptions http_communication_failure = 1
                              http_invalid_state         = 2
                              http_processing_failed     = 3
                              others                     = 4 ).

  response = client->response->get_cdata( ).

  out->write_json( response ).

  client->close( ).
endmethod.

Afterwards, the required data must be extracted from JSON. A simple transformation can be used for this. 

<?sap.transform simple?>
<tt:transform xmlns:tt="http://www.sap.com/transformation-templates">

<tt:root name="PORTS"/>

<tt:template>
  <object>
    <str name="type">FeatureCollection</str>
    <array name="features">
      <tt:loop ref=".PORTS">
        <object>
          <str name="type">Feature</str>
          <tt:group>
            <tt:cond>
              <str name="id"><tt:value ref="ID"/></str>
            </tt:cond>
            <tt:cond>
              <object name="geometry">
                <tt:value ref="POINT" option="format(geo=4326)"/>
              </object>
            </tt:cond>
            <tt:cond>
              <object name="properties">
                <tt:group>
                  <tt:cond>
                    <str name="port_id"><tt:skip/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond>
                    <str name="data_src_c"><tt:skip/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond frq="?">
                    <str name="port_coor_"><tt:skip/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond frq="?">
                    <str name="country"><tt:value ref="COUNTRY"/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond frq="?">
                    <str name="portname"><tt:skip/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond frq="?">
                    <str name="port"><tt:value ref="PORT"/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond>
                    <tt:skip/>
                  </tt:cond>
                </tt:group>
              </object>
            </tt:cond>
            <tt:cond>
              <str name="geometry_name"><tt:skip/></str>
            </tt:cond>
          </tt:group>
        </object>
      </tt:loop>
    </array>
    <tt:skip/>
  </object>
</tt:template>

</tt:transform>

The result can then be appended to an existing database table.

method modify_db_tab.
  data ports type standard table of my_ports_db with key id.

  try.
      call transformation my_ports_st
        source json feature_selection
        result ports = ports.
    catch cx_transformation_error into final(transformation_error).
      out->write( transformation_error->get_text( ) ).
  endtry.

  delete ports where country is initial or port is initial.
  modify my_ports_db from table ports.
endmethod.

The geodata is now available in the database table my_ports_db. A point characterizes each port. These points can be aggregated using the ABAP SQL function ST_ASSVGAGG.

select from my_ports_db
  fields st_assvgaggr( point )
  into table (svg_graphic).

To display all the ports as SVG in a browser, you can use ICF.

method if_http_extension~handle_request.

  select from my_ports_db
    fields st_assvgaggr( point )
    into table @DATA(svg_graphic).

  data svg_data type string.
  svg_data = svg_graphic[ 1 ].

  server->response->set_header_field(
    name  = 'Content-Type' "#EC NOTEXT
    value = 'image/svg+xml' ).

  server->response->set_header_field(
    name  = 'Expires' "#EC NOTEXT
    value = '0' ).

  server->response->set_cdata( svg_data ).

endmethod.

The result looks as follows:

Points of Ports in Europe

 

To give these points more context, we can add a European map. Several land maps are available on the web. For this demo, we use the Natural Earth map. Given the extracted files, geoJSON can be retrieved using GeoPandas. Using the following Python script, a JSON file is created.

import geopandas as gpd

# Load shapefile
gdf = gpd.read_file("ne_10m_admin_0_countries.shp")

# Ensure it's in 4326
gdf = gdf.to_crs(epsg=4326)

# Convert geometries to EWKT
gdf['ewkt'] = gdf['geometry'].apply(lambda geom: f"SRID=4326;{geom.wkt}")

# Save as TXT with EWKT
gdf[['CONTINENT', 'NAME', 'ewkt']].to_json("continent_name_ewkt.json", index=False)

You can then upload the JSON file to the system and prepare the data for inserting into a new database.

method load_europe_map.
  data file_data type table of string.
  data filename type string.

  filename = '/my_file_path/ne_10m_admin_0_countries/continent_name_ewkt.json'.

  cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_upload(
     exporting
       filename                 = filename
       filetype                 = 'ASC'
     changing
        data_tab                = file_data
      exceptions
        file_open_error         = 1
        file_read_error         = 2
        no_batch                = 3
        gui_refuse_filetransfer = 4
        invalid_type            = 5
        no_authority            = 6
        unknown_error           = 7
        others                  = 8
  ).

  data string_json type string.
    
  concatenate lines of file_data into string_json.

  data map_struc type my_map_db.
  data map_tab type standard table of my_map_db.
    
  data(json) = new cl_abap_json( string_json ).
  map_struc-id = 0.
  do.
    map_struc-name = json->get_value( |NAME.{ map_struc-id }| ).
    if map_struc-name is not initial.
      map_struc-continent = json->get_value( |CONTINENT.{ map_struc-id }| ).
      map_struc-geo_ewkt = json->get_value( |GEO_EWKT.{ map_struc-id }| ).
      append map_struc to map_tab.
      map_struc-id += 1.
    else.
      exit.
    endif.
  enddo.
    
  delete map_tab where continent <> 'Europe'.
  modify my_map_db from table @MAP_tab.
   
  commit work.

  update my_map_db set geometry4326 = st_geomfromewkt( geo_ewkt ) where length( geo_ewkt ) > 50.
  update my_map_db set geometry = st_geomfromwkt( st_aswkt( geometry4326 ), 0 ) where length( geo_ewkt ) > 50.
endmethod.

The database is now filled with the geodata needed to display the European map. With this underlying map, the ports are set into context.

method if_http_extension~handle_request.
  select from my_map_db
    fields st_assvgaggr( geometry4326 )
    where name <> 'Russia'
    union all
      select from my_ports_db
        fields st_assvgaggr( point )
  into table (svg_graphic).

  data svg_data type string.
  svg_data = svg_graphic[ 1 ].

  replace all occurrences of `grey` in svg_data with `#89D1FF`.
  replace all occurrences of `black` in svg_data with `#1B90FF`.

  server->response->set_header_field(
    name  = 'Content-Type' "#EC NOTEXT
    value = 'image/svg+xml' ).

  server->response->set_header_field(
    name  = 'Expires' "#EC NOTEXT
    value = '0' ).

  server->response->set_cdata( svg_data ).
endmethod.

The result now looks like this:

Points of Ports in a European Map

 

That's it. You have now seen one possible use case for displaying geodata using spatial data in ABAP SQL.

If you want to learn more about spatial data in ABAP SQL, explore the documentation. Additionally, a Devtober session about spatial functions in ABAP SQL is offered on 13 October 2025.

entry.title: Re: Transportation lane not passed to optimiser
entry.content:
Hello,

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI for Windows 8.10 Beta Program – Call for participation
entry.content:
I believe this is no longer a matter of personal taste. The distinction between read-only and editable text fields can simply be made through their background colors—for instance, a white background indicates an editable field (where input is allowed), while a gray background signifies a read-only one. This is a universal practice in UI design worldwide. There is absolutely no need to add extra solid black lines or dashed black lines at the bottom of text fields to differentiate between read-only and editable states. These obtrusive elements will severely compromise the overall aesthetics of the text fields. Especially when there are numerous text fields on a page, the abundance of dashed lines and prominent solid lines will look very distracting.
I believe UI design should prioritize simplicity, streamlining, and recognizability. It should adhere to universal UI design practices worldwide to reduce users' cognitive load for recognition.
I strongly recommend removing this feature!!
@FrankKrauseGUI

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI for Windows 8.10 Beta Program – Call for participation
entry.content:
So you see, distinguishing between editable and read-only text fields by using white and gray backgrounds is an excellent and sound design. Adding solid black lines and dashed black lines on top of this is somewhat redundant and unnecessary—it’s like "drawing a snake and adding feet" (a Chinese idiom meaning to do something extra that spoils the effect).

 

The contrast between these two old and new themes makes it easy to tell which one is more aesthetically pleasing and comfortable, and which one has unnecessary elements. The thick solid black line and dashed line under the text box are indeed quite redundant.

entry.title: How to validate mandatory attachment in Post General Journal Entries app in SAP S/4HANA Cloud?
entry.content:
Hello,

In the application ‘Post General Journal Entries’, the user requires a validation or an indication that prompts the processor to attach a mandatory supporting document. If no attachment is provided, the system should display an error message preventing the posting.

We have analyzed this requirement and attempted to implement a validation rule; however, we did not find any option related to attachments for validation. Additionally, we explored potential BAdIs to achieve this functionality, but unfortunately, no suitable option was found for this scenario.

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order Accrual - Tax postings in S4HC
entry.content:
Hello @DDA123 

BADI_ACE_DOCUMENT_SCHEMA_CLD in Public Cloud.
BADI_ACE_DOCUMENT_SCHEMA_CUST is the on-prem/private-cloud BAdI and is not the right one for S/4HANA Public Cloud. SAP’s KBA explicitly names the Cloud BAdI for changing accrual posting line items (_SCHEMA_CLD) and lists it under Accruals Management BAdIs in SAP Help.

 SAP Support Portal-3068511 - Which BAdI can be used to Modify Journal Entry Line Items when the Accrual Engine Performs the Posting of a Journal Entry?

If you want to avoid a BAdI entirely, your options are outside the Accrual Engine:

Post a separate FI tax or adjustment after the accrual, using Manage Journal Entries or Upload General Journal Entries, or clear to Post Tax Payables if that is appropriate.  SAP Help Portal-Manage Journal Entries (New Version)

Pre-calculate tax outside the system and record follow-up entries using standard applications or APIS, as the Accrual Engine does not perform complete tax determination. (SAP documentation and KBAs on the Cloud BAdI support this scope.)  SAP Support Portal-3068511 - Which BAdI can be used to Modify Journal Entry Line Items when the Accrual Engine Performs the Posting of a Journal Entry?

Additionally, KBA 3256557 illustrates the use of that BAdI, together with BADI_ACE_DOC_FIELDS_MAPPING, to populate a custom field, such as the trading partner from the purchase order, in accrual postings. SAP Support Portal/3256557 - How to add Trading Partner to Accrual Engine - S/4HANA Cloud

Let me know if you need further information.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Establish trust in global account and subaccount fails
entry.content:
Trust Establishment Issues | SAP Help Portal

Depending on the status code, verify the following points:
400: Check the section, Specific IAS tenant is not shown. Further, verify that the /sap/rest/identity-providers/ias REST API returns the used IAS tenant.
401: REST API requires a token of the apiaccess service plan from your subaccount.
404: For newly created IAS tenants, it can take up to 2 hours until the DNS entry is propagated to all the DNS caches. Until that is done, you can get an error when trying to call the new IAS tenant. In such a case, wait and retry after 2 hours.
